comments.commentBody: My parents were pulled out of rural areas -- she from Maine, he from Oklahoma -- by the lure of decent jobs to be found in California, created by the best work project imaginable -- World War II. The US completely stopped worrying about debt and focused on winning the war -- in the process saving an abandoned generation that achieved prosperity we can only envy. Surely we can still bring this new jobless generation into a new era of prosperity. There is still a lot of work to be done.

The fear in the financial crisis that came to a head in the fall of 2008 was not among the ordinary workers about to lose their jobs, their homes etc but among the elites.

We know now that they've made out like the proverbial and actual bandits that they are, but they are still running scared and shooting everything in sight, which is the rest of us. The Koch brothers are reported to be planning to buy the Tribune newspapers. Easier to keep the populace down if you control big sources of information.

The "entitled" (ie the elderly, the veterans, the poor, the sick et al) will be "unjustly" protected from their improvidence and folly. Never mind that the dangerous improvidence and folly was among the bankers and the big corporations etc. But they've pretty successfully circled the wagons and keep shooting at everyone else. The dreaded 47% of Romney's nightmare. The students saddled with huge loans. The 99% of the Occupy movement.

The best analysis of the mentality of the elites is by Chris Hayes in his insightful book, "Twilight of the Elites."

The elites are not misled by errors in economic analysis by Reinhart and Rogoff, though it surely is convenient for them.

Your point is well taken.However, the political landscape will not allow your conclusions to be acted upon. Odd, in a way, because these very same budget hawks were the ones who gave us the debt in the first place. I used to think technology had a lot to do with our structural unemployment. They had an economist on Bloomberg who insists the opposite is the case. My personal belief is that technology has benefited the rich disproportionately. It allowed them to globalize their work force and outsource jobs. The result is that we have become a service oriented society, driven by consumerism and home building. So I guess it makes sense to stake those who work in services to a stipend so they can increase consumer spending.  Same for housing. Waiting for the private sector to fill in the blanks might turn out to be a very long wait.  I personally don't see much change in the Congress coming. So we are trapped on snowball earth for another four years.

As a nurse I can attest to this. Hospitals want new nurses, right out of training,  lower salaries. They don't want experienced nurses who are at the top of the job pay scale. I was forced out as I was at the top of the heap, working on call, over time and as much as they "called," making more than the CEO. They found a way to get rid of me. Salary, salary.

Often companies suffer too because they pass over highly qualified and experienced individuals like Bruce and take low quality workers who are able to keep one step ahead of the pink slip by job hopping.

I didn't work for one year because I voluntarily resigned due to my father's poor health. For much of the following year I helped care for my dad. Near the end of that year, in early December 2010, my father died. In January 2011, a month later, I began looking for another nursing position. Because I hadn't worked for more than six months, but with 20+ years of experience, it took me five months to find a job, in a field in which open positions existed. To potential employers the reason or reasons didn't matter why I hadn't worked for more than six months. That I was qualified didn't matter.
Six months of unemployment as the sole or most important criteria for disqualifying someone from getting a job is arbitrary, unreasonable, and harmful to the job-seeker and to the job-seeker's family and community, when no other criteria is or are given equivalent consideration. It's wrong.

A succinct masterpiece of a column. Krugman boils down the folly of our economic policy to a few words. The key point is that it's a *deliberate* policy decision. It doesn't have to be this way. But the monied interests--including the majority of debt squawkers you see every Sunday on shows like "This Week"--use debt hysteria for their own ideological ends. It's been a massive fear campaign to shift the tide back toward the GOP, and too often Obama has played into it by speaking in their rhetoric. (The infamous "belt-tightening" phrase that falsely equated government finances with those of a family.) It's time to shout these truths more loudly.
There was an article in the NYTimes this weekend about  the Danish welfare system & how it no longer is doable because of the large number of able body people who never work but only collect.

We are simply going to have to convince the pubic that 99% of Americans would be better off if we were a colony of Denmark.  The Danes know how to govern in a civilized fashion, and we obviously don't.  Even with the current wave of "conservatism" sweeping that European country, it still has a degree of economic justice that our people can scarcely conceive of.

Many employers have caught on to this "trick" and are now ignoring self-employment that does not span several years and you have to back it up with real projects or work.

It stinks that employers are passing over someone who has the needed skills and experience because they have been out of work "too long" or are over 45 and viewed as too old. Nothing will change until government steps in to level the playing field so all qualified workers have an equal shot at getting a job. Right now employers are holding all the marbles.

I appreciate Dr. Krugman's warnings in this column: long-term unemployment is never a viable option, and leads inexorably to skills erosion.

I suggest that those members of the unemployed who are able to do so brand themselves as self-employed contractors or consultants. This allows them to write off their job hunting as business development activity and to avoid the stigma of unemployment for at least three years.

While this is not a permanent solution, it might ease transition.

After a while being under employed and unemployed becomes your brand. It becomes the image you see when you look in the mirror. The only economics indicators you feel are ones that deal with basic survival.

It wasn't suppose to end like this.

Employers used to train workers and pay employee tuition if they took courses to improve their skills. There were apprenticeships. Work has been evolving since the industrial revolution and people have been replaced by machinery since then, but there are plenty of people jobs - however, it's cheaper to outsource the work than to train employees. The job market has shifted in the employer's favor to the extent that if you haven't already done the job you are applying for, too bad. Try going into debt to get the required certificates, if there's a place to get them. If outsourcing weren't so profitable and tax rewarded it would be a different story.

As to the CCC, which hired young men for work in the parks, we still use what their unskilled work produced. I occasionally volunteer for work like that, and, guess what? There's still lots of it to be done.

I was criticized recently for a post in which I said jobs such as highway and bridge construction now take skills that were not required in the 1930s. One critic, a small contractor in an eastern state tied to say he and his crews could build bridge abutments and foundations for instance. Today it requires special licenses, and specialized equipment operators for these projects, along with a certified engineering staff.

I pointed out that the RRs would hire qualified electricians at good wages, but that the regular construction electrician would not qualify. One critic tried to say that those people could be retrained without much difficulty. That shows an ignorance of just what the difference in skills and education are for these two kinds of electrical work. Just as a house electrician can not just hire on as a HV lineman, repair and trouble shooting of RR engines takes special skills, education, and training. All electrical work is not just hoking up a couple of wires.

The RRs are hiring welders, but you have to be certified and pass special testing requirements. So today's job market is not like the WPA days, where you went to a camp and built National Park lodges. There were some great craftsmen on those jobs, and people with great building skills, but they were not in the majority.

Today most of those jobs are done buy machine. We could use cop and teachers, but 5 or 6 million? Again it takes education and training.

Will not work. Employers see self-employment as being synonymous with unemployment. After all, if a person were successfully self-employed - running a viable business and his own boss, why would he be looking for work?

Anetliner Netliner, Great Comment. Part of the permanent solution is a series of small steps like the one you suggest. Many larger employers frown on hiring entrepreneurs, because they see them as disruptive to the regimen, but it is good to try.

Many people don't have the entrepreneurial spirit it takes to step up, self educate, and stimulate the personal growth needed. It doesn't mean they are not smart, or good, just a different personality type. A great but somewhat dated book is the E-Myth, Why Most Small Businesses Fail, by Michael Gerber.

Another important part of the getting people back to work solution is dealing with industry consolidation, the Walmartization of the US economy. Partial globalization and monopoly have left people with a lot of cheap junk and no job.

Even in the vaunted tech arena consolidation and the throttling to come, through a few giant bandwidth owners promises to squeeze even the strongest self starters.

Megan, David and I are all correct:  entrepreneurship is not a solution for everyone, and entrepreneurs are sometimes viewed as disruptive.  I agree that the economy has been consolidating, making self-employment difficult. But for the skilled and the highly motivated, it can be a bridge across unemployment and, for a very small minority, a path to success. No, it is neither easy nor a path for everyone.

I suggest that those members of the unemployed who are able to do so brand themselves as self-employed contractors or consultants. This allows them to write off their job hunting as business development activity and to avoid the stigma of unemployment for at least three years.

While this is not a permanent solution, it might ease transition.
This is actually a very good response.  I am also frustrated with Obama's failure to comprehend the pain and suffering caused by high unemployment.

We have crossed a Rubicon and have found that America has turned a corner, from which there is no turning back. The study conducted at Northeastern University underscores what many have come to realize -- the music has stopped and there are but a few chairs left on which to sit.

The whole corporate Darwinism scare is now realized. Some nameless person summed it up very succinctly: The definition of middle class is having a job. What really freaks out those who don't have wealth is that there are crosshairs pointed at everyone currently in a job, as corporate America is a hungry wolf, and its appetite is voracious -- i.e., one day you are sitting on top of the world, the next, you're cashing out your 401(k) to stay afloat. We are all targets (except the 1%). See related articles on the coming class war.

Obama refuses to deal with unemployment for the very same reason he can't get behind climate change initiatives -- they're too insurmountable. Our economy, 70% of which is based on consumer spending, is untenable. You can't have a "consumer" nation, especially a imperial superpower that relies on consumption to fill the gas tank.

We can talk about deficits, Darwinism, greedy capitalists, corporate monsters all day long, but until someone at the top addresses these life and death issues, I fear more of the same from the type of wackos who terrorized us in Boston. If we can put a man on the moon, we can create jobs, and protect the planet. Or else...

The debt that has been accumulating during the Obama admisistration is the continuing result of two useless wars started by the Bush administration, the bush tax cuts, Bush's unfunded Medicare Part D program and the rest was the natural result of a loss in revenue and increased governmental costs related to the recession caused by Wall Street and de-regulation.
Green industries supported by the government haven't been collapsing right and left. A few did fail, but many more of the government's investments worked out well. Any investments made in start up companies carry risk but in the case of green industries that promise to promote growth and stimulate the economy, such risks are well worthwhile.
Obama's investments aren't unusual. Virtually every President in the last 80 years has made them. And I dare say that Obama's rate of making investments that eventually failed is probably muchlowerr than Romney's record in the private capital market. .Even if they had all gone bad, that would have represented a drop in the deficit bucket hardly worth mentioning.
By the way, deficits are now declining as the economy improves. If there is something to criticize here it is that Obama has been actively promoting deficit reduction when he should have been increasing the deficit to create demand.

Haha right.  Your sarcasm is funny, but your analogy is strange.  It does prove a point however.  Even common items can be utilized to make highly destructive weapons and no ban or regulation is going to make much difference except hinder law abiding citizens and blend us all into a homogeneous statist union of lemmings who only need to do what they are told and pay tax.  But whatever, keep thinking about justice in Michigan.
What fascists?  Who are you even talking about?

@dwb --

The "blame the victim" meme is really a new low!

"Instead of 'merely' pushing background checks..." ? It's the fault of the majority if Americans that our craven Senate voted against background checks?

If you can explain how background checks infringe ANY rights, much less 2nd Amendment rights, I'm ready to hear the reasons.

Meanwhile, all I can infer from the intransigence on this simple issue is that you and other gun owners, the NRA and the gun lobby prefer that criminals, convicted felons, domestic abusers, the adjudicated mentally ill, terrorists and political assassins have ready access to guns rather than that you be "inconvenienced" by paperwork.

Or you have bought into the preposterous propaganda of the NRA that any sane gun safety regulation "criminalizes" law-abiding gun owners.

Why is "law-abiding" always in quotation marks preceding "gun owner" ?

Our "patriots" in the House of Representatives are starving the "public estate" or want to sell it off.  Compare JFK to any other great airport in the world or look at the engineering reports on the state of our bridges and roads or better yet, visit Europe and experience the infrastructure there, the highways, the rapid transit systems, etc.  The Democrats are unable to get any real spending bill thru the House as they are all hysterical about the fact that Social Security may go bankrupt (then why don't they correct that problem at least if they are so concerned) that they are starving the rest of the "public estate" including our greatest national treasure, our children.

I realize that there is income inequality. However, as long as we have our public estate we can maintain our relative wealth. Parks, libraries, schools, highways, infrastructure, etc., are contributions from other generations that enrich us all.

What kind of patriot would threaten what our ancestors have given us?
Ron Paul? Ted Cruz? The modern Republican party?

(Ask that question at the next town hall meeting you attend.)

Clairette,
you criticize the gun owners of Boston because they stayed out of the way of the cops?
What would you have to say if they hadn't?
And to answer your question, I think I know where all the armed civilians with guns were: at home; ready.

1. Why are all online media getting the blame? Why can’t she stand up for herself once to correct all of the online media?

2. What about Goemagic website? It is her company, which contained information that is not verifiable. Who is to blame?

3. During NCWIT Interview with Ping Fu, “[Introduction]: "...She holds graduate and post-graduate degrees in computer science and Chinese literature, and is an adjunct professor at Duke University."
Lucy: You have a Ph.D. in computer science, and you're also on the Duke faculty, as well as being the CEO of a high-tech company. What technologies do you see out there, in addition to DSSP, that strike
you as being really innovative?” Why didn’t she correct Lucy on the spot during her interview? That would be her best time and chance to correct inaccurate information about her, and stop misinforming the general public. Isn’t it?

5. Who spread all of the erroneous info to promote her?

6. Does this mean USCIS also have the wrong information at the time when she was given Outstanding American by Choice award? Should she correct USCIS and return her 2012 Outstanding American by Choice award?

@John R. Arizona

Why can you not carry a gun in D.C. with a valid permit from your state? The doctrine of states' rights, much beloved by Red States, comes to mind. You want that gun in Arizona, keep it there.

But more to the point, perhaps the majority of Americans prefer to contain your cartoonish vision of the Wild West, where every man can be armed like the John Wayne he longs to be, on their movie and TV screens, or at Disney Land.

The common man's "right to self defense" as spelled out in DC v Heller, refers to defense within the home.
I favor CCW reciprocity, but not at the expense of the poor tattered Tenth Amendment.

The supply of dollars is infinite. Dollars, after all, are nothing more than certified IOUs. If they appear to be scarce, it's because Congress is rationing and Wall Street is hoarding.
Why does Congress ration the currency? Because it makes them feel powerful.

The problem with government spending is that is controlled by those people who make the rules about spending, but they are beholden to larger interests outside of congress--the businesses themselves. And the FED is part of the problem. With practically zero interest on loans, everybody and their mother's uncle is borrowing at the FED and making a bundle. It is the revolving door problem. Bernanke spends the taxpayer money (which is dwindling as we write) and the big money boys are borrowing, investing and making a killing on the market flipping sub-prime car loans, more bubble-like real estate loans and the little guy--that is me and millions like me--get NO interest from our savings.
What we need is for the FED to raise interest to say 10%, then the banks and the guys sitting on wads of dough with have to find other ways of making money. So, the banks will pay higher interest if they have to rely on "small investors" e.g savers, and then those savers will get money via interest paid on savings, spend that money, driving the demand-production machine and hopefully create jobs by raising demand for goods

. The president has precious little power to create jobs (or anything else). As Commander in Chief of the military, he has final say on POWs and could have closed Guantanamo but chose not to.
Only consumer demand is going to create the impetus to create more jobs, and we need to rethink our globalization policies as well. High taxes on overseas manufacturing is needed.

"Animosities between Muslims and Buddhists had been kept in check during the country’s five decades of military rule."

This is just not true. The Burmese army under the Ne Win regime expelled Muslim Rohingyas from Arakan State in 1978, and its successor the State Law and Order Restoration Council did the same thing in 1991-92. The military regime was frequently behind anti-Muslim violence in other parts of Burma, including in Prome and Taunggyi in 1988 and Mandalay in 1997. Although Burmese Buddhists are not on the whole especially fond of Muslims, everyone in the country knows that communal violence has been stoked by the powers that be.

No military regime has recognized the Rohingyas as citizens of Burma, and the 1982 Citizenship Law placed Muslims and others of non-indigenous ancestry into a second class citizenship category. Official discrimination against Muslims in Burma has a very long history.

There are thousands of jobs in the agriculture industry that have been filled by those 'Illegals" that so man worry about. the fact is there are not enough Americans willing to take those jobs with the hours, hard labor, and low pay that comes with them. Yet whole communities were built up around these workers who bought trucks, clothing, food, and the conveniences they could not afford in their own country.

That brought work to many more who worked in stores and industry supported by these customers. You and many other will try to tell us that farmers, chicken farmers, ranchers and others in these businesses only need to pay more. That shows ignorance as to how prices for those goods are set. These rural producers make contracts in the futures markets. They do not go to the wholesale market and say I want so much a bushel, their incomes are set a year ahead of time, then they set the wages they can pay and still stay in business.

We need those immigrant itinerant agriculture workers. As time goes on, many of them also open their own businesses, and their children go on to college.

You can see this progression in the history of the Japanese who came here as farm workers, then went into their own businesses despite rampant racism. Today it is almost impossible to find a Japanese gardener, their kids got educated and became professionals. That is the story of immigrants, legal or illegal, The economy progresses because of them, they help create wealth.

Recent immigrants are a new group that it is hoped can be safely segregated. They are not yet a "protected class."
The hierarchists among us are absolutely certain that society will crumble if it is not sustained by a heirarchy. So, a hierarchy has to be created, somehow and that means some group has to be segregated and assigned to the bottom.
Segregation is not necessarily antagonistic. Arranging people in categories is what some people need to perceive a well-ordered society.

There are at least three elements to your assertion that deserve consideration.

First, the future IS an unknown, and will be. Any change in immigration policy will result in something different, so fearing the future is reality, and if you're really that scared by such change, whatever it may be, then I guess you're suggesting we do nothing instead. Somehow that's the problem right now...we've refused to confront reality and try to do "something."

If your assertion about millions coming to seek the new jobs were valid it proves the other two things.

The non-skilled, manual labor work goes to those willing to do it, and sadly it's been shown time and again that most Americans simply won't do that work, even if they have no particular qualifications to do other things. Those "feared immigrants" are taking work nobody else is willing to do. Of course, they're also picking the food crops you expect to see in your local market.

The "high tech" workers to which you refer may or may not be going to new immigrants, but if they are it's most likely because the companies are unable to fine Americans able to do the job. Since most unemployment is not structural in nature, that's not likely to be anything we can fix simply be denying an immigrant the job.

In short, the future WILL be different, even if we do nothing. How different, and different in what way we might just have to wait and see.

Paul, I hope you read these reader comments because I have an urgent request.  We have heard the message regarding austerity vs stimulus a million times and simply repeating yourself further is a waste of ink. Instead, what the republic urgently needs is to get your advice regarding immigration reform. Truly earth shattering legislation has been proposed by the gang of eight in the  senate and if it passes our nation will be embarked on an irreversible trajectory into a mysterious future. Under the proposed law, legal immigration of both high tech and unskilled workers will vastly increase. In addition many million of illegal aliens will be given work permits to begin competing for jobs in the regular labor market. How will this legislation effect the economy and unemployment? Is it true that the new immigrants will stimulate demand and investment and reduce unemployment  (as some claim)? Alternatively, is it true that competition from the new immigrants make life even more difficult for those currently unemployed. Do we really need the new workers? The reform law is supported by president Obama and by a strange coalition including both labor unions and the chamber of commerce. Other politicians oppose the law and have been accused of racism and nativism. Please write a column explaining what you think of these matters. It is a topic that is timely and where your input could make a critical difference to the fate of millions of people.
